notes: On 1 April 2019, two motorcyclists came into a compound where an activist campaigning for the Election Commission's impeachment in Bang Kapi district in Bangkok city, and set the activist's vehicle on fire with gasoline. A petition document that had been left in the vehicle was partly burned. The activist suspects the military government to be behind the destruction.

On 31 March 2019, a well-known redshirt activist was physically attacked by two unidentified assailants who broke into his home in Samut Prakarn province, after the activist had returned from demonstrating in Bangkok city to demand the impeachment of the Election Commission. He suffered minor attacks on his left arm.

On 31 March 2019, several hundreds of opposition activists staged demonstrations in Bangkok near the Erawan Shrine and at the Victory Monument with banners reading "Cheating Election" and "People Want to Vote." They were demonstrating to have the Election Commission members dismissed, since they conceded errors in tabulation of the results. They were also soliciting signatures for a petition. [size=several hundreds]

On 30 March 2019, a group of assailants assumed to be SMS opened fire on a man and woman, a rubber latex trader and a clerk, riding in a pickup in Ban Phruja village in tambon Nod, Saba Yoi district, Songkhla. The victims succumbed to their injuries at the hospital.

On 30 March 2019, when an army major and three soldiers were driving back to their barracks from a wedding Ban Sakor village in Su-ngai Padi district, Narathiwat province, a bomb went off in front of their pickup truck followed by a number of assailants leaving hiding places and opening fire on the truck. One bullet hit the major in the leg and the assailants, suspected to be SMS, fled. The police dispatched to investigate the scene had a second bomb go off near them, 70 metres away from the first, but no one was injured by it.

On 28 March 2019, a group called "the Green World Network in Phetchabun" staged a demonstration march through the Mueang Phetchabun municipality, Phetchabun, to campaign against the oil exploration plan in Phetchabun's Si Thep district, 1.3km away from Si Thep Historical Park, fearing that the park would lose its status as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. [size=no report]

On 26 March 2019, unidentified persons set fire to a car owned by an activist campaigning for the Election Commission's impeachment in Bangkok city. The car owner managed to put out the fire to keep it from being damaged too much. The activist suspects the military government to be behind the destruction.

On 19 March 2019, residents in five provinces gathered to demonstrate and submit an official letter to the Government House in Bangkok city, to ask the government to review the planned construction project of the third Bangkok Western Outer Ring Road, which would interfere with their homes and farmland. [size=no report]

On 19-March-2019, in Songkhla city, Songkhla province, a former police officer was shot and killed in front of his home. The victim was known for campaigning against corruption. Police are still searching for the perpetrators.

On 16 March 2019, the police pulled over three suspected pickup trucks involved in drug trafficking on Phahon Yothin Road in tambon Pasang of Mae Chan district, Chiang Rai province. A man in one of the three pickups allegedly opened fire and the police returned it. The officers found one man dead while the other two drivers surrendered. The trucks contained 8 million speed pills.

On 16 March 2018, around the world hundreds of thousands of students and young people left classrooms and staged demonstrations in support of the World Youth Climate Demo. Such protests were held in Bangkok. [size=no report]

On 15 March 2019, an unknown number of men suspected to be Southern Muslim Separatists opened fire at a Yala-bound passenger train in Rueso district, Narathiwat province. The attack slightly damaged the train but caused no injuries.

On 14 March 2019, a woman was killed when a bomb targeting rangers exploded in Sompoi village in tambon Kayomati, Bacho district, Narathiwat province. The bomb was hidden under piles of wood and went off shortly after a patrol pickup truck carrying rangers drove past. The rangers escaped unhurt but the shrapnel and wood killed a female civilian who was nearby.

On 13 March 2019, two suspected Southern Muslim Separatists dressed as women arrived on a motorcycle and hurled a pipe bomb at the living quarters of a police protection unit at Subotasae village in Yi Ngo district, Narathiwat province. The attack caused no injuries. The police fired four shots at the two attackers but they successfully fled the scene.

On 12 March 2019, two soldiers and a villager were wounded in bomb and shooting attacks on a military outpost in tambon Ko Sathon, Tak Bai district, Narathiwat province. 5-6 armed suspected Southern Muslim Separatists opened fire and soldiers returned it for 5 minutes before the separatists fled. Then other assailants arrived on a motor tricycle and stuffed a cooking gas cylinder on the road in front of the outpost, before it was shortly detonated. The explosion caused the boatshed and outpost to catch fire and burn to the ground. Soldiers tried to combat the fire and the assailants threw two more pipe bombs at the soldiers before fleeing.

On 11 March 2019, a patrol ranger from the 48th Ranger Regiment was injured by a hidden roadside bomb during his foot patrol in a team of six rangers near Ban Sala Road in Chuab subdistrict, Cho-Airong district, Narathiwat province. The bomb was 2m from a campaign poster of an MP candidate of the Phue Khon Thai Party. Soldiers and police later found the scattered shrapnel and remnants of an IED detonated by radio signal in a 5kg iron box.

On 10 March 2019, two bombs exploded in front of a grocery shop at Moo 6 village in tambon Khlong Khut, Mueang Satun, Satun province at two different times early in the morning. No injuries were reported. Later police reports allege the bombs were planted by Southern Muslim Separatists.

On 10 March 2019, in Phatthalung's Pak Payoon district, there were three explosions: two explosions at two separate grocery shops in Moo 3 and Moo 11 of tambon Don Pradu; one outdoor explosion in Moo 11 of Don Pradu. There was also the discovery of a suspicious bomb item in Moo 9 of Don Pradu. Later police reports allege the bombs were planted by Southern Muslim Separatists.

On 10 March 2019, in Phatthalung's Pak Payoon district, there were six explosions: one explosion in a bicycle shop in tambon Pak Payoon; one explosion in a rubbish bin behind Anubal Pak Payoon School; one outdoor explosion in Pak Payoon; and an explosion inside a park near Phattalung train station. There was a bombing outside a plant-selling shop and also a bombing at an abandon house near the Pak Payoon Police Station. There was also the discovery of one suspicious bomb item behind a municipality sign in Pak Payoon. Later police reports allege the bombs were planted by Southern Muslim Separatists.

On 9 March 2019, two bombs exploded after they were planted in front of the provincial police office on Yatra Sawasdee road in Satun town, Mueang Satun, Satun province. The first exploded in a trash bin near a power post, and the second in an area holding impounded vehicles. No injuries reported. Later police reports allege the bombs were planted by Southern Muslim Separatists.

On 7 March 2019, a Muslim man was shot dead in a teashop by suspected Southern Muslim Separatists in Ban Buenae Pade in tambon Kadunong, Sai Buri district, Pattani province. The victim was drinking his tea when two men arrived on a motorcycle and one of them walked up to the victim and shot him once in the head. The attackers then fled the scene.

On 7 March 2019, as reported to the Rueso district police in Narathiwat province, three gunmen emerged from a rubber forest to open fire on an oncoming sedan. When the car lost control and swerved off the road, one of the gunmen opened the door and fired more shots directly at the victim. The three gunmen fled in a pickup that came to the scene. The police believe it is over a drug-trafficking conflict.

On 7 March 2019, about 10 people staged a demonstration at the Samui International Airport in tambon Bo Put, Ko Samui district, Surat Thani province to protest the insufficient compensation for the noise pollution from the airport by flying kites to block the end of the runway. Police and soldiers met with demonstrators and guaranteed to arrange a meeting for them so they would end the demonstration. [size=10]

On 6 March 2019, a Muslim wan was shot four times in his torso, right thigh, and right arm, and left severely wounded in Sungai Kolok district, Narathiwat province. Given the instability in Thailand's southern provinces, this violence could be the attributable to Southern Muslim Separatists.

On 6 March 2019, some 20 representatives led by P-Move were permitted to observe the National Legislative Assembly's discussions on the controversial amendment of the 1961 National Parks Act and its sister Wildlife Conservation Bill in Bangkok. They disrupted the meeting and tried to convince the NLA to scrap the two bills, as they are concerned about it allowing forest dwellers and communities to continue their existence in the forest. Police had to remove them after they refused to stop making noise. They were sent back to their campsite near Wat Benchamabophit. [size=20]

On 5 March 2019, an assailant hit a well-known activist with a wooden stick, injuring his arm and head after he went to the Public Health Ministry in Bangkok city, to report the alleged use of hate speech and incitement of violence by a pro-military medical worker.

On 4 March 2019, hundreds of security guards and their employers staged a demonstration outside the Government House gate in Bangkok to call on the government for help with the newly in effect Security Business Act BE 2558 (2015). The act lays out standards that security guards must now meet, and many of the current security guards say they have not been able to get their licenses in time. [size=hundreds]

On 3 March 2019, paramilitary rangers clashed with suspected Southern Muslim Separatists in Jeu Kor (Moo 5), Dusongyor in Chanae district, Narathiwat province. Gunfire was exchanged for 30 minutes but no injuries or fatalities were reported. The rangers were trying to track down the injured separatists from a battle on 2 March 2019.

On 3 March 2019, the body of a civilian was found lying behind the Sababu Islamiyah Mosque in Ban Rueso in Yaring district, Pattani province. He had been shot once in the back of the head. The police do not know the motive for the killing and say it probably could have been the result of a personal conflict. As it is in the Deep South, this violence might be linked to the Southern Muslim Separatist violence.

On 2 March 2019, a team of deployed paramilitary rangers clashed with 4-5 suspected Southern Muslim Separatists gathered at the foothill of a mountain in Ban La Lo (Moo 5) in Rueso district, Narathiwat province. One separatist was killed, several were injureed and an M16 rifle was seized. The separatists were believed to be members of the Barisan Revolusi Nasional (BRN).

On 2 March 2019, thousands of Thai Raksa Chart supporters staged a rally in the historic centre of Bangkok city, Phra Nakhon district, Bangkok, ahead of a Constitutional Court ruling on 7 March that could end their prospects in the national elections later that month. [size=thousands]

On 2 March 2019, throngs of Pheu Thai party supporters staged a rally in a stadium in Chiang Mai city, as the party members promised developments and incentives for entrepreneurs in the northern city. This was done ahead of a Constitutional Court ruling on 7 March that could end their prospects in the national elections later this month. [size=throngs]

On 28 February 2019, two men on a motorcycle shot and killed a soldier as he was returning to base after a football game in Ban Du Ku Surao, tambon Bareh Nuea, Bacho district, Narathiwat province. He was found severely injured and later died in hospital. Police believe the assailants are Southern Muslim Separatists.
On 27 February 2019, unidentified gunmen shot a man dead in Pattani province. As it is in the Deep South, this violence might be linked to the Southern Muslim Separatist violence.

On 26 February 2019, two policemen were abducted at gunpoint by eight armed men wearing military-type uniforms from a tea shop in tambon Bu Kit, Cho-Airong district, Narathiwat province. They were then shot and dumped in a ditch 200 meters from where they were abducted. The stolen vehicle used in the abduction was found burnt out in the neighbouring Tak Bai district. The assailants, which given the violence in the region was most likely done by Southern Muslim Separatists, have fled and taken possession of an M16 rifle and two 9mm pistols that belonged to the slain policemen.

On 26 February 2019, around 100 men staged a demonstration at the Bang Khunthian police station in Bangkok, demanding that the 24 men detained there for disturbing university entrance exams on 24 February apologise for their actions. [size=100]

On 26 February 2019, a roadside bomb exploded at Ban Ubae village in tambon Bacho in Bannang Sata district, Yala province, when a paramilitary ranger team was patrolling the road to provide protection for teachers. One ranger was killed and another injured. A female civilian on a motorcycle nearby was also injured. Police placed responsibility for the bomb on the Southern Muslim Separatists. Bomb disposal officers found a second bomb nearby after investigating the scene and safely destroyed it.

Reported on 25 February 2019, business operators and locals staged a demonstration in the area of Kata Noi beach in tambon Karon, Phuket province, against the construction of a luxury condominium in the area. [size=no report]

On 24 February 2019, a group of 24 young men raided and disturbed a secondary school's admissions exam by ordering the students and teachers to leave, damaging the room and injuring a security guard at Matthayom Wat Sing School in Bang Khuntian district in Bangkok when complaints about the noise of their music were lodged. In total, 12 people reported being injured and some schoolgirls and teachers alleged sexual harassment. [size=24]

On 24 February 2019, three Myanmar workers were shot and wounded by the son of a pork shop owner where they live in Mahar Chaing market in Samut Sakhon province. This occured following an argument that occurred between the son and the workers.

On 21 February 2019, a shootout between drug traffickers in two Toyota trucks and police broke out early in the morning on a road leading to Moo 4 village of tambon Pa Sang in Mae Chan district (Mae Chan, Chiang Rai) after police were waiting due to a tip-off. A five-minute exchange resulted in one of the drivers, an Akha Hill Tribesman, being shot dead, while the other fled on foot and escaped. Large amounts of pills were found.

On 21 February 2019, anti-paraquat organizations, the Thai Pesticide Alert Network, Biothai Foundation and farmers staged a demonstration outside the Ministry of Industry in Bangkok city (Phra Nakhon, Bangkok) against the decision for a toxic herbicide linked to Parkinson's disease to be approved by officials for use in Thai agriculture for two more years. [size=no report]

On 21 February 2019, more than 200 employees continued their week-long demonstration against the Gamakatsu International Co in Ban Khlong Nueng (Khlong Luang, Pathum Thani) for its decision to suspend operations in response to the labour union's request for better pay and benefits. [size=200]

On 20 February 2019, small groups of pro- and anti-military activists staged conflicting demonstrations on Ratchadamnoen Avenue in Bangkok City (Phra Nakhon, Bangkok) to express opinions on the army chief's choice to play an anti-communist song from the mid-1970s over the army's radio outlets and army units. One side said the lyrics accused political opponents of undermining society, whereas the other side was for the military's choices. About 50 police supervised and kept the groups separated. [size=small groups]

On 20 February 2019, police said Southern Muslim Separatists opened fire on a Buddhist temple in Moo 5 village in tambon Ban Klang (Panare, Pattani). Witnesses said there were 10 gunshots but none of the 5 monks living there were injured.

On 19 February 2019, a local resident and his wife while driving home were targeted by a drive-by shooting by two men, suspected southern Muslim separatists, on a motorcycle between tambon Koror and tambon Karubee in Raman district (Raman, Yala), resulting in the resident's death. His wife escaped unharmed.

Defusal: On 19 February 2019, on Inthamara 55 Road in Din Daeng district in Bangkok city (Phra Nakhon, Bangkok), after identifying a suspect placing what looked like bombs, an IED and L56 practice grenade, at the base of a power pole from surveillance camera footage, police closed the road and bomb experts removed them. It was later discovered that the practice grenade was powerless and the other was fake. They do believe it was intended to be a threat.

On 17 February 2019, about 50 motorcycle taxi operators staged a demonstration at a checkpoint between Thailand and Malaysia in Sadao district (Sadao, Songkhla) and obstructed the passages of vehicles in protest against Malaysia's strict inspection of documents on motorcycle taxis taking passengers from the checkpoint to the duty-free shop. [size=50]

On 17 February 2019, a ranger was shot dead in his home in Moo 10 village in tambon Pawong in Mueang Songkhla district, in Songkhla province when a gunman inserted a barrel through the front door and opened fire, hitting him in the chest. The police haven't established motive, but the assailants are believed to be suspected southern Muslim separatists.
On 14 Feb 2019, in Chokaladee village, Yaha district, Yala province, two farmers were killed at a fruit plantation by gunmen (suspected separatists).

On 14 February 2019, more than 200 employees began demonstrating and striking against the Gamakatsu International Co in Ban Khlong Nueng (Khlong Luang, Pathum Thani) over their refusal to acquiesce to the labour union's request for better pay and benefits. A day later the company suspended operations. [size=200]

On 14 Feb 2019, in Ban Pa Phai village, Tambon Tanyong, Ra Ngae district, Narathiwat state, a bomb exploded when four rangers were approaching. No one was injured. A makeshift shelter for vendors was damaged. It is suspected that the bomb was planted by Southern Muslim Separatists.

On 12 Feb 2019, in tambon Pasemat, Sungai Kolok district, Narathiwat state, two gunmen (suspected separatist) on a motorcycle opened fire at two Malaysian nationals at a garage. One was killed and the other was wounded.

On 11 Feb 2019, in Ailakho village, tambon Chang Phueak, Chanae district, Narathiwat state, a gun battle between security forces and suspected separatists took place. Two separatists were shot dead and four to five were wounded.

On 11 Feb 2019, in Min Buri district of Bangkok, the police shot and killed a vocational student during a gun battle. After a drug raid, the student had followed the police car and during the ensuing firefight he was killed. The police were accused of using excessive force.

On 10 Feb 2019, at Village Group 7 of tambon Pulo Puyo in Nong Chik district, Pattani province, two men (suspected separatists) on a motorcycle opened fire on a villager who was riding a motorcycle with his nephew. The villager was seriously wounded and later pronounced dead at the hospital.
On 10 Feb 2019, at Village Group 5 in tambon Lahan, Sai Buri district, Pattani state, a villager on a motorcycle was shot and killed by two men (suspected separatists) on another motorcycle.

On 5 Feb 2019, in Ban Sipo village, Tambon Chalerm, Ra-ngae district, Narathiwat province, suspected separatists opened fire at a civilian defense official of Ra-ngae on a motorcycle. He sustained injuries and was brought to hospital.

On 4 Feb 2019, in tambon Pasemat, Su-Ngai Kolok district, Narathiwat province, suspected separatists opened fire on a police officer on a motorcycle. The officer was injured and a civilian, who was passing by, was killed.

On 3 Feb 2019, in Da-oh Mamah, tambon Ban Klang, Panare district, in Pattani province, a Muslim man was shot and killed by suspected separatists when walking on the street. [The police initially suspected a personal conflict, but did not rule out that separatists were involved.] 1 fatality.

On 2 Feb 2019, in Bangkok, five pro-democracy activists, among them students, protested in front of the Government house, demanding the prime minister's resignation. The activists tried to submit a letter to the PM and hung dried chilies, salt and garlic on the fence (traditionally burned to curse some one). They were arrested by the police.

On 28 Jan 2019, near Ban Si Tha Nam, in Than To district, Yala province, a border patrol policeman was killed by separatists. After an alert from local residents, he had left his station at Ban Sri Tha Nam School to check a cooking gas cylinder left by the roadside where he was ambushed by an unknown number of men.

On 27 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, protesters from a network protecting Nakhon Si Thammarat-Phatthalung land, water and forest rallied at the Government House to protest against the government's water projects in the South.

On 26 Jan 2019, in Ban Rai village, tambon Che Hae, Tak Bai district, Narathiwat province, a small bomb detonated by a rental house as soldiers on motorcycles were passing by. The bomb, made of a plastic water bottle, is suspected to have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. No casualties.
Around 26 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, a Vietnamese blogger for Radio Free Asia (RFA) appeared to have gone missing after applying for asylum at the UN Refugee Agency.

On 26 Jan 2019, near Ban Khokin, tambon Chuap, Cho Airong district, Narathiwat province, a bomb, buried in a drain, exploded when a truck carrying a team of rangers drove past it. It is suspected to have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. The explosion damaged the road, but no one was injured.

On 26 January 2019, unknown assailants set a well-known activist's car on fire outside his house in Bang Kapi district in Bangkok city. This was most likely in retaliation for the activist speaking out to demand the government hold elections without further delay.

On 25 Jan 2019, in Ban Ba Sa Weng village, tambon Krong Pinang, Krong Pinang district, Yala province, a bomb exploded wounding three civilians and three police officers providing protection for teachers. Authorities blamed Southern Muslim Separatists and believed it was the work of a group led by Yahya Bueraheng.
On 25 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, residents from Nakhon Si Thammarat demonstrated against the construction of the Wang Heeb Dam in Thing Song district.
On 25 Jan 2019, in Mueang Phuket, Phuket province, Rawai and Nai Harn locals held a protest against the rise in Dengue Fever cases in the area.

On 19 Jan 2019, near Ban Ta Ya Lo, tambon Tuyong, Nong Chik district, Pattani province, a bomb exploded on the side of a road. Security authorities blamed separatists. Two policemen, patrolling the route on teacher protection duty, were seriously injured.

On 19 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, 30 to 50 people gathered at the Democracy Monument protesting for national unity and against unrest caused by rallies against election delays. Meanwhile, hundreds of people gathered at the Thammarat University to demand an end to delays in the general election. The group had moved the planned protest away from the Democracy Monument to avoid clashes with opposing protesters.
Around 19 Jan 2019, in Tambon Thung Tako of Thung Tako district, Chumphon province, a vocational student was shot dead and found two days later in a creek in a rubber plantation.

On 19 January 2019, four assailants punched and kicked a well-known activist near Thammasat University in Bangkok city, after he was returning from a protest demanding that the government should hold elections without further delays.

On 18 Jan 2019, in Ban Tue Kor, tambon Chanae, Chanae district, Narathiwat province, police and paramilitary rangers raided a rubber plantation when encountering five armed suspected separatists. During the following gunfire one separatist was killed, presumably others were wounded.

On 18 Jan 2019, in To Deng, Sungai Padi district, Narathiwat province, a bomb (suspected to have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists) exploded at To Deng train station when a soldier and five paramilitary rangers were patrolling the area. The patrol opened fire into roadside bushes. A second bomb exploded, wounding five of them.

On 18 Jan 2019, in Ban To Deng, Sungai Padi district, Narathiwat province, a group of suspected separatists entered at Wat Rattananuparb, a Buddhist temple, shot several rounds and then escaped. Two monks were killed and two injured.

On 16 Jan 2019, in Khon Kaen, Khon Kaen province, about 40 Khon Kaen University students staged a protest at the university gate against delays to the general election. Nearly 40 police officers checked IDs of the protesters but did not intervene.
On 16 Jan 2019, in Ban Klong Haeng village, tambon Khao Phanom, Khao Phanom district, Krabi province, a woman was shot and killed by two gunmen hiding on the plantation next to their house.

On 16 Jan 2019, in Ban Tha Ngio, Nakhon Si Thammarat province, hundreds of students of Rajabhat Nakhon Si Thammarat University staged a protested demanding the university director to resign. The students were accusing him of abusing his authority and making questionable decisions on school affairs.

On 13 Jan 2019, in Napradu, Khok Pho district, Pattani province, at least six men (suspected southern separatists) on motorcycles opened fire on the Napradu police station. A police sergeant was shot and killed.

On 13 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, about 150 people staged a protest at Ratchaprasong Junction against delays to the general election. The protesters were demanding the election be held before the king's coronation in May.
On 13 Jan 2019, in Chiang Mai, Chiang Mai province, about 20 people staged a protest at the city hall against delays to the general election.
On 13 Jan 2019, in Chiang Rai, Chiang Rai province, a protest was held to demand an end to delays in the general election.
On 13 Jan 2019, in Ubon Ratchathani, Ubon Ratchathani province, a protest was held to demand an end to delays in the general election.
On 13 Jan 2019, in Phayao, Phayao province, a protest was held at the provincial hall to demand an end to delays in the general election.

On 13 Jan 2019, in Nakhon Pathom, Nakhon Pathom province, a protest was held to demand an end to delays in the general election. Among the protesters were several public figures, including a deputy leader of the Future Forward Party.
On 13 Jan 2019, in Maha Sarakham, Maha Sarakham province, a protest was held to demand an end to delays in the general election. Among the protesters were students of the Maha Sarakham University.
On 13 Jan 2019, in Khon Kaen province, a protest was held to demand an end to delays in the general election.

On 13 Jan 2019, in Moo 7 village, Kabang tambon, Kabang district, Yala province, suspected separatists entered the house of two MP candidates of the Thai Nation Power Party, tied them up and shot them dead.

On 12 Jan 2019, in tambon Talorkapor (Yaring, Pattani), a five hours clash took place between the police and suspected southern separatist allegedly linked with the school shooting on 10 Jan 2019. Two separatists were killed. A volunteer ranger and an eight-year-old child were slightly injured.

On 10 Jan 2019, in tambon Prachan (Yarang, Pattani) about eight armed men dressed like soldiers (suspected separatists) opened fire on defence volunteers at Bukoh school. Four defence volunteers were killed.
On 9 Jan 2019, in Chiang Mai (Mueang Chiang Mai, Chiang Mai), about 200 people marched under the banner of 'Walk to Vote' against further delays to the general election scheduled for February.

On 9 Jan 2019, in Nakhon Ratchasima (Mueang Nakhon Ratchasima, Nakhon Ratchasima) people demonstrated at the Thao Suranari Monument against further delays to the general election scheduled for February.

On 8 Jan 2019, in Ban Nikhom, tambon Tha Muang (Thepha, Songkhla), a bomb exploded near Huai Pling police station in a car that was recently stolen by separatists. Authorities suspected the Barisan Revolusi Nasional (BRN). The explosion destroyed a power transformer causing a widespread blackout. Two soldiers were injured.

On 8 Jan 2019, in Ban Pong Sakhor in tambon Moh Mawee (Yarang, Pattani), a bomb detonated in front of a local non-formal education center. It is suspected that it was planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. A private and a 12-year-old schoolgirl were injured.
On 8 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, hundreds of protesters staged a demonstration at Ratchaprasong intersection against delays in the national election scheduled for February.

On 7 Jan 2019, Saba Yoi district (Songkhla), suspected separatists killed a retired teacher and used his pickup truck to launch a car bomb that detonated early next day near Huai Pling police station. Authorities suspected the Barisan Revolusi Nasional (BRN). 1 fatality.
On 6 Jan 2019, in Bangkok, around 100 pro-poll activists gathered at the Victory Monument to demonstrate against a possible delay of the general election planned for 24 Feb.
Around 5 Jan 2019, in Mae Fah Luang district (Chiang Rai), a firefight took place between army rangers and drug couriers at the Thai-Myanmar border. Four drug suspects were killed.
A bombing took place related to separatism/independence. No injuries, no fatalities.

On 30 Dec 2018, in Ban Bae Rae village, tambon Bor Ngor (Ra-Ngae, Narathiwat), two bombs exploded damaging two roadside power poles. It is suspected that they have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. No casualties.
On 29 Dec 2018, in Pattani province, a woman was shot and killed in an attack by suspected Southern Muslim Separatists.

On 29 Dec 2018, tambon Si Sakhon (Si Sakhon, Narathiwat), suspected separatists ambushed a pickup truck carrying three rangers. During the subsequent gunfire, the three rangers were seriously injured.

On 29 Dec 2018, in tambon Pado (Mayo, Pattani), an assistant to the chief of tambon Pado was shot and killed by a gunman (suspected separatist) hiding in front of his house. The assistant was known to be active in drug suppression. 1 fatality.

On 29 Dec 2018, near Ban Ya Ba (Rueso, Narathiwat), at least four bombs exploded, damaging train tracks, a cell phone-signal pole and an electricity pole. The bombs were suspected to have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. No casualties.
A dead body was discovered. It unclear what caused the death.
A shooting took place with unclear motives. One fatality (a woman) reported.
A shooting took place with unknown causes. Guns were used. One injury and no fatalities reported.
Four bombings took place related to separatism/independence. No injuries, no fatalities.

On 28 Dec 2018, tambon Ka Li Sa (Ra-Ngae, Narathiwat), a number of armed men (suspected separatists) opened fire on a security outpost. Subsequently the armed group and defence volunteers exchanged fire for 30 minutes. Meanwhile, another group blocked the way to the outpost by cutting a tree and scattering metal spikes over the road. No fatalities noted.
On 28 Dec 2018, Chanae district (Narathiwat), four bombs exploded near power poles and a bridge. It is suspected that they have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. No casualties.
On 28 Dec 2018, Khok Yamu village (Tak Bai, Narathiwat), a bomb explosion damaged a power pole. It is suspected that it was planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. No casualties.
A bomb was defused, resulting in zero injuries and zero fatalities. The bomb was planted for separatist/independence related reasons.
A shooting took place with unclear motives. One fatality reported.

On 28 Dec 2018, Si Sakhon district (Narathiwat), two bombs exploded. One went off under a bridge in Sakor village, tambon Sri Sakhon, injuring four villagers. The second damaged a power pole at La-or village in tambon Sri Banphot. It is suspected that they have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists.
Six bombings took place related to separatism/independence. No injuries, no fatalities.
On 28 or 29 Dec 2018, in Ban Bo Thong (Ra-Ngae, Narathiwat), a bomb exploded near a roadside power pole. It is suspected that it has been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists. No casualties.
Security measures: On 27 Dec 2018, Songkhla, (Muang, Songkhla), security authorities closed Samila beach and nearby roads after two bombs exploded at the beach the day before.

On 27 Dec 2018, in Mukdahan province, a candidate of the newly established New Alternative party was shot and killed by unknown. Other party members suspect a local gang killed him as he was investigating a corruption case. 1 fatality.

On 27 Dec 2018, in That Phanom district, Nakhon Phanom province, a body, wrapped in brown sacks along with blocks of cement, was found on the shore of the Mekong River. DNA tests show that he was one of three exiled activists, associated with the anti-military red shirt movement, who disappeared in December from Laos.

Defusal: On 27 Dec 2018, Songkhla, (Muang, Songkhla), security authorities found and destroyed three bombs at Samila beach after two bombs had exploded the day before. The police suspected Barisan Revolusi Nasional.

Defusal: On 27 Dec 2018, tambon Tha Chang (Bang Klam, Songkhla), security officials found and destroyed fours bombs attached to four power poles. It is suspected that they have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists.
A shooting took place with unclear motives. One fatality reported.
An attack/clash involving firearms took place. No injuries, no fatalities. The event was separatism/independence related.
On 26 Dec 2018, tambon Bang Riang (Khuan Niang, Songkhla), two bombs damaged two high voltage power poles (suspected to have been planted by Southern Muslim Separatists). No casualties.
On 26 Dec 2018, Songkhla, (Muang, Songkhla) two bombs exploded around 10:30 pm at Samila beach. No casualties, but two sculptures were damaged. The police suspected Barisan Revolusi Nasional.

Police believe the bombs were planted in a motorcycle and a car and are connecting it to previous militant blasts in the area in March.

An unidentified gunman fired at the home of former prime minister Chuan Leekpai in Trang province in an attack which police believe was politically motivated. No one was hurt in the incident.

On 31 December 2013, in Phuket city (MP, Phuket), the PDRC supporters sealed all gates of the registration center at the provincial public hall, blocking electoral officials from entering. Constituency MP candidates were not allowed to enter the center to register.

The attack took place at the demonstration site at Suan Misakawan intersection in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok).

The attack occurred in Uthai district (Uthai, PNSA) and was the fourth shooting on her home since she had joined the yellow-shirt People's Alliance for Democracy (PAD). No one was injured in the attack.

Police believe the attack was the work of a third party who wanted to create trouble to exacerbate the situation.

On 28 December 2013, in Krabi city (MK, Krabi), a group of demonstrators led by the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC), gathered in front of the election center to demonstrate against the election and bar candidates from registering. No violence was reported.

In Chumphon, the election registration venue was surrounded by more than 100 anti-election demonstrators who also cut water and electricity supplies. Candidates were not able to get inside, but no violence was reported.

In Nakhon Si Thammarat, election officials were not able to enter a building they had planned to use for candidate registration work after anti-government demonstrators gathered at the site and used loudspeakers to criticize the government and the Election Commission.
Anti-government demonstrators in Phuket blocked poll officials from performing their duties and register candidates for the upcoming election.
In Songkhla, anti-government demonstrators surrounded the election registration site and did not allow candidates to enter.
In Surat Thani, demonstrators laid siege to the registration venue for the upcoming election and no candidates turned up to register.
Anti-government demonstrators in Trang blocked poll officials from performing their duties and register candidates for the upcoming election.

A five-year-old girl was killed in a gun attack which was intended to target her father, the village chief, in Pattani's Panare district in tambon Pho Ming. The attack occurred outside the chief's home as three or four unknown gunmen opened fire on him. No other details were reported.

One ranger was killed by a bomb explosion in Yala's Yaha district while on patrol to provide security for teachers. The attack occurred as eight rangers were on foot patrol in tambon Baro when a bomb hidden in roadside bush was detonated. No other details were reported.

On 27 December 2013, an active social media user Kittichai Ngamchaipisit organized netizens and staged a candle-lighting demonstration at the Bangkok Art and Culture Centre in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok) against the PDRC's "Bangkok Shutdown" planned for 13 January.

A policeman was killed during clashes with anti-government demonstrators at the Thai-Japanese Stadium in Din Daeng district. The violence also left 26 other officers and 70 demonstrators injured. Clashes erupted at the stadium as anti-government demonstrators under the Network of Students and People for Reform of Thailand tried to break into the stadium's grounds to obstruct the drawing of the party-list candidacy numbers. Most of the injured suffered the effects of tear gas, rubber bullets and were hit with unknown hard objects. Later reports were updated to say that a demonstrator died on injuries in the hospital later.

A group of unknown attackers launched two M79 grenades on a police outpost on Dec 26 and opened fire on the base with automatic weapons in Narathiwat province. The attackers fled after security officials returned fire. No other details were reported.
An ambush on a ranger patrol squad wounded three in Narathiwat province on Dec 26. The attackers fled after security forces returned fire. No other details were reported.

On 26 December 2013, about 3,000 anti-government demonstrators from the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC) rallied for the second time outside the empty house of the caretaker Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra in Bueng Kum district (BK, Bangkok) and called for her to resign.

A taxi driver was beaten by a group of anti-government demonstrators after he complained about traffic congestion on the Vibhavadi-Rangsit road in Bangkok after it was blocked by demonstrators. The demonstrators also attacked the taxi itself.

The demonstrators were mostly from Network of Students and People for Reform of Thailand.

Soldiers from the Narathiwat Special Task Force 31 narrowly escaped injury in an explosion in tambon Praiwan of Tak Bai district while they were patrolling in their pickup truck. No other details were reported.

The demonstrators had converged on the police station that day to demonstrate that they had not been allowed to register their candidacy for the general election. No one was injured.

On 23 December 2013, about 2,000 anti-government demonstrators surrounded Din Daeng police station in Din Daeng district (DD, Bangkok) after election candidates and Election Commission (EC) officials arrived to file complaints that they could not enter the Thai-Japanese Stadium to register. Led by the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC), the demonstrators blocked all gates at the police station and demanded a meeting with Din Daeng police.

A tambon administration organization (TAO) member was killed and three villagers wounded by gunmen in Yala's Bannang Sata district. The attack took place as the victims were sitting outside of a mosque in tambon Bannang Sata. A group of men emerged from the forest and opened fire. No other details were reported.

Three simultaneous bomb attacks rocked Songkhla's Sadao district, wounding 24 people. The explosions occurred in front of the Padeng Besar Police Station, the Sadao Besar Police Station and the Oliver Hotel. Many of the wounded were at the hotel. Security officials said the blasts were likely the work of separatists.

On 22 December 2013, People's Democratic Reform Committee leader led a large number of supporters in a march from Wong Wien Yai to join another group of waiting demonstrators at Silom in Bang Rak district (BR, Bangkok) in order to push for Yingluck Shinawatra to resign.

A group of anti-government demonstrators, mostly women and transvestites, marched to the house of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra in Soi Yothin Pattana 3 Bung Kum district in Bangkok. About 3,000 demonstrators gathered there to demand she step down.

On 22 December 2013, anti-government demonstrators assaulted a female reporter from Channel 9 television because they were not satisfied with her live reports. Demonstrators threw water, hit and pulled on the reporter in an attempt to bar her and her team from leaving the Government Lottery Office building on Ratchadamnoen Ave in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok). The office is close to the Democracy Monument, where the main anti-government demonstration site led by the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC) is set up.

They would return to the Democracy Monument later in the day. The statement explains why Thailand needs reform before an election, not promised afterwards.

On 19 December 2013, the anti-government demonstrators marched through downtown Bangkok and gathered outside the US embassy in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok) to demonstrate against Washington's support of the Feb 2 general election. More than 15,000 people joined the march, which started from the Democracy Monument then headed to Bangkok's business district of Siam, Ratchaprasong, Asoke and Pratunam. The group was largely affiliated with the PDRC and the NSPRT and their aim was to invite the public to their upcoming rally to call for the ousting of Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra.

Youth on motorcycles attempted to enter the rally site and scuffled with the PDRC security guards. Fireworks and small explosives were thrown, wounding a security guard and an attacker.

On 6 December 2013, a People's Democratic Reform Committee security guard was shot and injured by unknown assailants at a rally site at the Ministry of Finance in Phaya Thai district (PT, Bangkok). Two men on a motorcycle were reported opening fire on the guard before fleeing.

About 800 anti-government demonstrators in Prachin Buri blew whistles to protest a public hearing on the 350-billion baht flood and water management scheme. The hearing was held in Si Maha Phot district and was aimed to discuss a plan to build flood walls in the province. Demonstrators claimed they had not been informed about the forum.
Anti-government demonstrators rallied at national police headquarters on Rama 1 Road in Bangkok, demanding an explanation about police operations resulting in hundreds of injuries a few days ago.

The demonstrators declared that they would continue their demonstrations until it defeats the "Thaksin regime" and appoints a people's council to head the government.

Clashes between anti-government demonstrators and police continued for a second day, spreading to four sites and injuring a total of 119 demonstrators. Three people were shot while others mostly suffered from tear gas explosions. The skirmishes resumed as thousands of demonstrators tried to break through police barricades to get into the Metropolitan Police Bureau (MPB) and the Government House. Other classes were reported at Orathai Bridge near the Government House and the Karn Ruan intersection near Parliament.

Three policemen were seriously wounded by a bomb blast in Narathiwat's Chanae district. The bomb exploded while a group of police on patrol were on their way to tambon Chang Phuak to investigate the scene of another bomb explosion. No other details were reported.

On 2 December 2013, tensions rose when pro-government supporters clashed with anti-government demonstrators near Phor Khun Mengrai Monument in Mueang Chiang Rai district (MCR, CR). About 50 UDD Red Shirts reportedly jeered and cursed at a 100-strong group of anti-government demonstrators as they were marching toward the provincial hall. Minor injuries were reported.

Anti-government demonstrators managed to break through barriers to enter the compound of the Interior Ministry in Bangkok. During the scuffle of the break-in, one policeman was injured.

Police hurled tear-gas canisters at a crowd of anti-government demonstrators attempting to march to the Government House as they approached Panichayakarn intersection and Chamai Maruchet Bridge in Bangkok. Police also turned water hoses on others at different rallying points. The demonstrators reportedly responded by throwing objects back at the police.
A bomb exploded in tambon Chang Phuak in Narathiwat's Chanae district, targeting a 12-strong ranger patrol. None of the rangers were injured and no other details were reported.

On 1 December 2013, a group of anti-government demonstrators took control of Thai PBS television station on Vibhavadi Rangsit Road in Dusit district (Dusit, Bangkok). They were led by a core member of the People's Democratic Reform Committee (PDRC). The demonstrators told the TV channel to stop broadcasting government announcements and to televise speeches made by PDRC leaders and Democrat Party programs.

7,000 demonstrators were prompted to return to the Government Complex and the Finance Ministry areas of Lak Si district, Bangkok, to prevent them from being seized back by police. The report did not mention whether there was a confrontation between the two groups.
Anti-government demonstrators in Buriram marched to their provincial hall and called on government officials there for support in their campaign against the current government.
Anti-government demonstrators in Nakhon Si Thammarat marched to their provincial hall and called on government officials there for support in their campaign against the current government.

Anti-government demonstrators in Satun marched to their provincial hall and called on government officials there for support in their campaign against the current government.

In Uttaradit, around 200 kamnans and 300 village chiefs took part in the anti-government campaign and marched to their provincial hall to call on the government officials for support in their anti-government campaign.

At Ban Khaena of tambon Bang Khao in Nong Chik district of Pattani, seven people were attacked while foraging in the forest. Three or four unknown gunmen opened fire on the group from motorcycles, killing four. The gunmen are believed to be members of the Runda Kumpulan Kecil (RKK) separatist group.

A deadly shooting took place in Kapho district of Pattani in tambon Karubi. The victim was returning home when a gunman riding pillion on a motorcycle fired at him and fled. No other details were reported.

A man was shot to death while his son and daughter were wounded in a gun attack in Pattani's Panare district. The incident took place in tambon Ban Klang while the family was riding home on a motorcycle. Unknown gunmen opened fire on them and then fled. Police were still investigating.

In Ratchaburi, about 1,000 demonstrators who entered the provincial hall clashed with officials. The officials had shut the gate to the provincial hall to prevent more demonstrators entering. But eventually the demonstrators reopened the gate. No injuries were reported.

Four cases of arson took place in Khok Pho, Khok Pho, Pattani. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one incendiary device was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

Two cases of arson took place in Makrut, Khok Pho, Pattani. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one incendiary device was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.
Arson took place in Na Pradu, Khok Pho, Pattani. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one incendiary device was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.
Arson took place in Pa Bon, Khok Pho, Pattani. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one incendiary device was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

On 30 November 2013, tensions outside Bangkok flared when around 3,000 anti-government demonstrators encountered 300 Red Shirts at the provincial hall in Samut Prakan city (MSP, SP). United Front for Democracy against Dictatorship (UDD) supporters, some carrying sticks, taunted the anti-government demonstrators outside the compound. The standoff led to a brawl as red shirts allegedly chased the demonstrators, who threw water bottles back in return. No injuries were reported in the incident.

On 30 November 2013, four people were killed and 57 wounded in street battles between Ramkhamhaeng University students in Bang Kapi district (BK, Bangkok). Tensions soared as the anti-government demonstrators attacked a bus carrying Red Shirt supporters, throwing stones and objects. Gunshots were later fired near the stadium and stabbings were reported.

On 30 November 2013, the Democracy Party leader lead thousands of anti-government demonstrators to the Department of Special Investigation (DSI), CAT Telecom and TOT Plc. headquarters near the Government Complex on Chaeng Watthana Road in Lak Si district (LS, Bangkok). The demonstrators began marching from the Government Complex to these nearby headquarters in accordance with a plan for a "total seizure" of key government agencies over the weekend to set in motion "the people's revolution."

On 30 November 2013, thousands of UDD red shirts supporters have begun streaming into Bangkok to join the mass pro-democracy rally at Rajamangala Stadium in Bang Kapi district (BK, Bangkok). The UDD red shirts red shirts vowed to prolong their gathering to "protect democracy" until the anti-government demonstrators end their campaign.
Crowd control police were hit by ping-pong bombs hurled at them by the anti-government demonstrators at the Makkawan Rangsan Bridge in Bangkok. No major injuries were reported, however.

On 29 November 2013, a leader of the Democrat Party led supporters in in a demonstration march to submit a letter to the US embassy on Witthayu Road in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok), declaring the coalition led by Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra has no legitimacy to govern. Members of the Business Club for Democracy and alumni and current students of many educational institutes were also gathered at Asoke intersection to in defiance of the government and joined the march to the US embassy.

Defiant Thai opposition demonstrators stormed the army headquarters and besieged Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra's Pheu Thai party offices, intensifying their fight to bring down her government. The demonstrators are a mix of royalists, southerners and urban middle class.

On 28 November 2013, anti-government demonstrators were on the move in Bangkok, making symbolic takeovers of more government offices. From their base in Ratchadamnoen Avenue, a number of demonstrators moved to the Defense Ministry, the Education Ministry and the Royal Thai Police. They were led by leaders from the Democrat Party and the People's Democratic Force to Overthrow Thaksinism (PEFOT).
In Nakhon Ratchasima, about 1,500 anti-government demonstrators rallied at Suranari Monument and marched to the 2nd Army Region headquarters and to the provincial hall.

On 28 November 2013, tensions rose in Pathum Thani city (MPT, PT) when pro-government supporters clashed with anti-government demonstrators during the latter's march to the provincial hall. The Red Shirts cursed and hurled bottles of water at the 100 anti-government demonstrators. Some demonstrators sustained minor injuries in the skirmish before police intervened.

Six territorial defense volunteers and one civilian were injured by a bomb explosion on a road in Mueang district of Yala province. The bomb exploded in tambon Sateng when the volunteers were on duty at a security checkpoint on the opposite side of the road. No other details were reported.

On 27 November 2013, about 3,000 demonstrators converged on the provincial hall in Krabi city (MK, Krabi), following instructions by the leader of the Democrat Party to take control of government offices in all provinces, to cripple the government and show their defiance toward the Yingluck Shinawatra administration.

On 27 November 2013, anti-government demonstrators converged on the main provincial offices in Nakhon Si Thammarat city (NST, NST), following instructions by the leader of the Democrat Party to take control of government offices in all provinces, to cripple the government and show their defiance toward the Yingluck Shinawatra administration.

Over 1,000 anti-government demonstrators, led by the Network of the Students and People for Thailand's Reform, demonstrated in Trang province. It was one of at least six provincial halls in the southern region of Thailand that were occupied by anti-government demonstrators in order to show their defiance of the administration.

On 27 November 2013, a large crowd of supporters of the People's Democratic Force to Overthrow Thaksinism (PEFOT) surrounded the Energy Ministry's offices in Chatuchak district (Chatuchak, Bangkok), blocking all gates, on Vibhavadi Road. The demonstrators demanded that government officials at the ministry stop working for the state and go home.

Anti-government demonstrators continue to demonstrate in Bangkok, besieging government buildings to challenge the Yingluck administration. Up to 10,000 demonstrators gathered at a large office complex on the northern outskirts of Bangkok that houses key government agencies. In addition, groups have dispersed to march to other key offices, including: the Labor Ministry, the Social Development and Human Security Ministry, the Industry and Information and Communication technology ministries, and the Public Health and Commerce ministries.

In Chumphon, more than 1,000 anti-government demonstrators converged on the main provincial offices. It was one of at least six provincial halls in the southern region of Thailand that were occupied by anti-government demonstrators in order to show their defiance of the administration.

In Phuket, about 1,000 demonstrators gathered in protest in front of the provincial hall. It was one of at least six provincial halls in the southern region of Thailand that were occupied by anti-government demonstrators in order to show their defiance of the administration.

In Satun, anti-government demonstrators converged on the main provincial offices. It was one of at least six provincial halls in the southern region of Thailand that were occupied by anti-government demonstrators in order to show their defiance of the administration.

In Songkhla, anti-government demonstrators converged on the main provincial offices. It was one of at least six provincial halls in the southern region of Thailand that were occupied by anti-government demonstrators in order to show their defiance of the administration.

Well over 1,000 demonstrators gathered at the provincial hall in Surat Thani. It was one of at least six provincial halls in the southern region of Thailand that were occupied by anti-government demonstrators in order to show their defiance of the administration.

On 26 November 2013, demonstrators gathered at their provincial hall in Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya city (PNSA, PNSA) and blew their whistles to express their defiance of the government. They were led by the Democrat Party and were planning on leaving for Bangkok to join the rallies there.

On 26 November 2013, demonstrators continue to occupy key offices and ministries in Bangkok , including the Agriculture, Tourism and Transport ministries. The demonstrators were mostly led by the People's Democratic Force to Overthrow Thaksinism (PEFOT).

On 26 November 2013, demonstrators led by the People's Force for Democracy to Overthrow Thaksinism (PEFOT) and Kong Thap Tham (Dhamma Army) succeeded in surrounding the Interior Ministry offices in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok), blocking all gates and declaring they would rally there for three days.

A paramilitary ranger was critically injured by a bomb explosion on a road in Ra-ngae district of Narathiwat province. The bomb was detonated in tambon Tanyongmas while a ranger company was on foot patrol. Police blame separatist militants.

On 25 November 2013, demonstrators marched across Bangkok and occupied the Budget Bureau office in Dusit district (Dusit, Bangkok) to put pressure against the government as part of their attempt to stamp out what they call the "Thaksin Regime." Once there, the group cut all electricity and water supply systems. The group was led by the Democrat Party.

Members of the Network of Students and People for Thailand's Reform (NSPTR) rallied in front of the Foreign Ministry in a protest against the minister, accusing him of serving the interests of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra.

On 25 November 2013, demonstrators occupied key ministries in Bangkok in a bid to topple the government. In their first moves, the demonstrators entered the Finance Ministry, the Budget Bureau, the Foreign Ministry and the Public Relations Department (PRD). They are led by The People's Force for Democracy to Overthrow Thaksinism (PEFOT) and Kong Thap Tham (Dhamma Army).

Anti-government demonstrators at the Democracy Monument and in Sanam Luang in Bangkok started their marches to 13 government agencies and television stations. Hundreds of thousands of supporters turned out to show their strength against the government. The demonstrators will march to 13 state offices, headquarters of the four armed forces and television stations.

Anti-government demonstrators occupied the area outside the Government Public Relations Department in Phaya Thai district in Bangkok. The demonstrators were gathered as a symbolic move to emphasize the fact that the PR department should be the mouthpiece of the people.

Anti-government demonstrators were accused of assaulting journalists at rallies in Bangkok who they believe supportive of the administration led by prime minister Yingluck Shinawatra. Demonstrators attacked a German freelance reporter after a speaker at a rally urged them to chase him away because he was affiliated with the United Front of Democracy against Dictatorship (UDD). The reporter was punched in the face several times until police intervened.

A bombing took place in Kosit, Tak Bai, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one improvised explosive device (IED) was used. There were 1 injuries and 0 fatalities.

On 24 November 2013, the United Front for Democracy against Dictatorship (UDD red shirts) held a mass rally in Bang Kapi distric (BK, Bangkok) to counter growing anti-government protests and to show support for the Yingluck Shinawatra administration. The rally took place at the Rajamangala National Stadium.
Anti-government demonstrators estimated in the hundreds of thousands joined a rally at the Democracy Monument, in order to support the ousting of the Yingluck government.

The leaders of the three main anti-government protest groups joined forces, vowing to fight shoulder-to-shoulder to uproot former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra's political networks and initiate national reform. The demonstrators gathered at the Democracy Monument in Bangkok and included demonstrators from the Network of Students and People for Thailand's Reform (NSPTR) and the Dhamma Army.

Four soldiers were seriously injured by a bomb explosion on a road in tambon Tha Mueang in Thepha district of Songkhla province. The explosion occurred in front of a mosque while the soldiers were patrolling the road. Police blamed separatist militants.

Anti-government protest groups threatened to cut off electricity and water at state offices in the capital and at Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra's residence. The move was aimed at escalating the push to oust the Yingluck government. The demonstrators were mostly gathered at the Democracy Monument in Bangkok, while the Students and People for Reform of Thailand (NSPRT), based at the Makkhawan Rangsan Bridge, and the People's Democratic Force to Overthrow Thaksinism (PEFOT) at the Phan Fa Bridge, remained at their sites.

A man was shot and killed in an ambush in Pattani's Sai Buri district. The victim was walking along a rural road in tambon Trohborn when an unknown gunman fired at him from the forest. No other details were reported.

Three police officers were wounded when a home-made bomb was hurled behind the barricade near Makkhawan Bridge that prevents outsiders from entering off-limits zones. Officials believe the incident could be linked to an attempt to instigate unrest in Bangkok, as earlier reported by intelligence police.

A woman was shot and killed and her husband, a police officer, seriously injured in an ambush in Yala's Mueang Yala district on Nov 22. They were attacked while they were driving a motorcycle home. In Ban Po Yo, an unknown number of gunmen emerged from a roadside bush and fired at the couple. The officer shot back at the attackers and they fled the scene.

A search took place in Tanyong Limo, Ra-ngae, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to counter-insurgency activities. At least one infantry firearm was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities. State forces assumed to be military. State forces assumed to be military.

A search took place in Sawo, Rueso, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to counter-insurgency activities. No weapons were used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities. State forces assumed to be military. State forces assumed to be military.

A bombing took place in Pak Lo, Khok Pho, Pattani. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one improvised explosive device (IED) was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

A policeman manning a barricade at Makkhawan Rangsan bridge on Ratchadamnoen Nok Avenue in Bangkok was slightly injured when a firecracker or ping pong bomb was thrown at him by an unidentified person. Police were still investigating.

The Silom Thailand group, comprising white-collar workers and business operators in Silom area, gathered to demand that Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra accept and follow the ruling of the Constitution Court. The group gathered in front of the Silom Complex on Silom Road.

On 20 November 2013, UDD red shirts remain gathered at the Rajamangala Stadium in Hua Mak in Bang Kapi district (BK, Bangkok), saying they are likely to extend their two-day rally if they are unhappy with the Constitution Court's ruling on the make-up of the Senate. Over 20,000 were there to show their support for the Pheu Thai government.

A paramilitary ranger was shot and killed and his two younger sisters seriously injured on Nov 19 in a shooting in tambon Khlong Ma Ning in Mueang Pattani district of Pattani province. The victims were fired at while they were sitting in front of their home. Police were still investigating.

About 30 student representatives from Nawamintharachinutit Suankularb Wittayalai Pathumthani School converged on the Education Ministry in Bangkok to protest against their school director. The students want the ministry to investigate the director for alleged ineffectual school management.

On 19 November 2013, there was a mass gathering of UDD red shirt members at Rajamangala National Stadium da Thawornsat in Bang Kapi district (BK, Bangkok), ahead of the Constitutional Court's ruling on charter changes to the Senate. More than 100,000 were expected to join in the mass rally.

On 19 November 2013, three Cambodians were shot dead by Thai forces while allegedly illegally logging rosewood in Thailand, after they crossed the border from Oddar Meanchey province into Sisaket province, Thailand. The bodies were taken to be repatriated at the Cambodian Choam border crossing.

On 18 November 2013, the Democrat-led demonstration on Ratchadamnoen Avenue in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok) continued, with demonstrators calling for the government's removal of the amnesty bill.

About 30 people from farming and civic groups stormed a meeting room in the Agriculture Department in Bangkok, protesting against moves for Thailand to become a signatory of convention on new plant varieties, as they believe it violates the rights of farmers to save seeds.

Two defense volunteers were wounded by an improvised bomb thrown from a motorcycle while providing security at a school in in tambon Pen in Sai Buri district of Pattani province on Nov 18. The attack was committed by two unknown men. No other details were reported.

Three bombings were reported in Thepa district of Songkhla province. The first bomb exploded at a mobile phone signal post, while the second and the third one, planted some ten meters away, were triggered about ten minutes later. There were no injuries and no other details were reported.

A shooting took place in Bang Khao, Nong Chik, Pattani. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one firearm of an unknown type was used. There were 1 injuries and 0 fatalities.

A suspected militant was killed in a clash with security forces in Ra-Ngae district of Narathiwat province on Nov 16. The clash took place after a joint police and military force raided an abandoned house in tambon Bo Ngo. Two militants opened fire and the sides exchanged gunfire, leaving one dead.

The student-led demonstrators from the Network of Students and People for Reform of Thailand used flagpoles to chase anti-riot officers near the Nang Loeng race track as police tried to block their march to Government House. But the demonstrationleaders quickly intervened to calm the angry demonstrators. One police officer suffered a minor injury. The demonstrators were set to march from their rally site at the Makkawan Rangsan Bridge to the security checkpoints set up by police in Dusit, Phra Nakhon and Pomprap Sattruphai districts.

A scuffle between police and villagers broke out in Kamphaeng Phet province, with two people held briefly for trying to attend a public forum on the government's water-management scheme. 500 villagers attended the forum and tried to enter the convention hall at Kamphaeng Phet Rajabhat University, before they were detained.

On 15 November 2013, 20 men are said to have attacked an officer behind the Democrat Party's rally staged on Ratchadamnoen Avenue near the Democracy Monument in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok). The injured officer claimed that the attackers were guards on duty to protect the demonstration site.

About 200 rubber growers from Prachuap Khiri Khan began protesting in front of the Agriculture and Cooperatives Ministry in Bangkok, demanding the government act quickly to tackle the problem of low rubber prices, reports said. The growers began their protest about noon, according to the reports.

At a rally site at the Makkhawan Rangsan Bridge in Bangkok, the Network of Students and People for Thailand's Reform (NSPTR) marched to the Silom business center to protest against the government's amendment of Section 190 of the Constitution and call on the government to urgently help Veera Somkwamkid who was arrested in Cambodia and imprisoned in the neighboring country.
The anti-government demonstration on Ratchadamnoen Avenue continued to demonstrate against the Shinawatra family and government in Bangkok.

The demolition of an explosive device took place in Batong, Rueso, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one fake explosive device was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

Three police officers were killed in a roadside bomb blast in Narathiwat's Ra-ngae district. The three officers had been assigned to escort teachers and were traveling in a pick up truck when the bomb exploded. No other details were reported.

Three paramilitary rangers providing security for teachers were injured by a bomb explosion on a road in Mai Kaen district of Pattani province. The rangers had been on foot patrol in tambon Talo Kraithong when a roadside bomb exploded. Police blamed separatist militants.

A violent disturbance involving the placement of traffic spikes took place in Kolo, Waeng, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one sharp weapon was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

A bombing took place in Kolo, Waeng, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one improvised explosive device (IED) was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

In Lampang, about 2,000 members of women's groups, residents and community leaders rallied at the provincial hall to express support for the government's amnesty bill and the Yingluck Shinawatra administration.

A paramilitary ranger was seriously injured on Nov 12 in an ambush in Yi-Ngo district of Narathiwat province. Rangers of 312 Company were patrolling on a rural road at Ban Bluka Sanor in tambon Ta Po Yo when gunmen hiding in roadside forest fired at them. The rangers fired back and the gunmen retreated. Police blamed separatist militants.

On 11 November 2013, demonstrators supporting the Democrat Party occupied Ratchadamnoen Avenue from Democracy Monument to Phanfa Bridge in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok) in order to demonstrate against the amnesty bill.

On 11 November 2013, three protest groups-the Anti-Thaksin Coalition comprising civic groups in all 77 provinces, The People's Democratic Force to Overthrow Thaksinism and the Dhamma Army-marched to the Defense Ministry in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok) to demonstrate their intention to reject the International Court of Justice's (ICJ) ruling on the Preah Vihear dispute.

A shooting took place in Tanyong Limo, Ra-ngae, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one infantry firearm was used. There were 1 injuries and 3 fatalities. State forces assumed to be military. State forces assumed to be military.

On 10 November 2013, independent UDD red shirts groups turned out in force to back the Pheu Thai leader and plead with opposition demonstrators to back off from trying to overthrow the government. Several thousand UDD red shirts supporters gathered at Muang Thong Thani and Ratchaprasong intersection in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok) to condemn those leading the anti-amnesty bill rallies.

A former village chief was shot to death in Pattani's Yaring district. The incident occurred in tambon Saban while the chief was travelling on a motorcycle and a gunman opened fire on him. Police were still investigating the motive.

In Pattani's Kapho district, assailants shot and killed the Karubi sub-district chief and wounded another village head while they were traveling in a pickup. Police were still investigating the motive.

Three soldiers and two villagers were wounded when a bomb exploded in the municipality of tambon Rueso in Narathiwat province. The homemade bomb was detonated as a military task force passed by. No other details were reported.

In Narathiwat province, one young man was killed and two other seriously wounded in a gun attack in Rueso district. The men were fired at in tambon Batong as they were riding motorcycles near a rubber plantation. No other details were reported.

A shooting took place in Karubi, Kapho, Pattani. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one infantry firearm was used. There were 1 injuries and 1 fatalities. State forces assumed to be military. State forces assumed to be military.

About 1,000 Thai Airways International employees defied the firm's request for "cooperation" and staged a rally against the amnesty bill outside the airline's head office in Bangkok. The demonstrators blew whistles, similar to other groups, to send their message opposing the bill and demand political reform.

On 8 November 2013, UDD red-shirt supporters of the government, numbering a few hundred in total held a demonstration in Chiang Mai city (MCM, CM) in order to express their backing for the Pheu Thai-led administration and the amnesty bill. No other details were reported.

On 8 November 2013, UDD red-shirt supporters of the government, numbering a few hundred in total held a demonstration in Pathum Thani city (MPT, PT) in order to express their backing for the Pheu Thai-led administration and the amnesty bill. No other details were reported.

On 8 November 2013, UDD red-shirt supporters of the government, numbering a few hundred in total held a demonstration in Rayong city (MR, Rayong) in order to express their backing for the Pheu Thai-led administration and the amnesty bill. No other details were reported.

A village head in Narathiwat province was killed in an apparent militant shooting attack. Assailants in a pickup truck drove by and shot him as he was leaving a teashop. No other details were reported.

A bombing took place in Pak Bang, Thepa, Songkhla. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one improvised explosive device (IED) was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.
Arson took place in Pak Bang, Thepa, Songkhla. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. It is unknown what type of weapons were used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

Around 500 dam demonstrators clashed with authorities at a public hearing on dam projects in the Yom River basin. Demonstrators from tambon Sa-iam of Song district in Phrae, who oppose the previously-proposed Kaeng Sue Ten dam, tried to break through crowd barriers and a line of 200 security officials to gain access to the meeting venue. No injuries were reported.

A police officer was injured in a clash with demonstrators from the Network of Students and People for Reform of Thailand in front of the UN building on Ratchadamnoen Nok Avenue. No other details were reported about the clash.

On 7 November 2013, a group of demonstrators led by the Democrat Party continues to hold ground at their protest site at the Democracy Monument in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok). They are continuing their protest against the controversial bill seeking blanket amnesty for offenders in corruption and criminal cases.

Opponents of the blanket amnesty bill, mostly office workers, converged at Asoke BTS station in Bangkok. The Asoke gathering was organized by the Businessmen for Democracy Club, which led similar rallies on Silom Road earlier in the week. The group blew whistles in a show of defiance against the bill and to promote "clean democracy."
The Network of Students and People for Reform of Thailand started marching its anti-government and anti-Thaksin demonstrators from Uruphong intersection towards Ratchadamnoen Avenue in Bangkok.

A number of Thammasat University's former students marched from the university's Tha Phrachan campus along Ratchadamnoen Avenue to Parliament in Bangkok. Their intention was to submit a letter calling for the Senate to reject the amnesty bill.

White-collar demonstrators protesting against the amnesty bill took to Silom Road for the second time to blow a storm of whistles, wave Thai flags and vent furious objections, leading to traffic jam in one of Bangkok's most hectic business centers.
The protesting group called the Dhamma Army continues to demonstrate at Phan Fa bridge in Bangkok, in opposition to the blanket amnesty bill.

A village headman was shot dead in Narathiwat's Mueang district. The attack occurred in front of a furniture shop at Ban Khok Sumu in tambon Bang Po when the chief was returning home from a tea shop when a gunman opened fire at him with an assault rifle, killing him on the spot. Police blamed separatist militants.

A clash took place in Sako, Si Sakhon, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one firearm of an unknown type was used. There were 0 injuries and 0 fatalities.

Thousands of state and private medical workers demonstrated in front of hospitals nationwide against the blanket amnesty bill, demanding the Senate withdraw the controversial bill from deliberation. A group of physicians at Siriraj Hospital organized a demonstration at the facility.

Pranangklao Hospital workers held a protest against the amnesty bill outside their facility in Nonthaburi province, as part of thousands of state and private medical workers who did the same nationwide.

Anti-amnesty demonstrators returned to occupy Silom Road in Bangkok, as they fear the Pheu Thai-led government might still try to legislate the controversial blanket amnesty bill. A crowd of about 600 gathered in Silom and joined the whistle-blowing campaign to show their opposition to the bill.

A bombing took place in Tanyong Mat, Ra-ngae, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one improvised explosive device (IED) was used. There were 5 injuries and 2 fatalities. State forces assumed to be military. State forces assumed to be military.

On 5 November 2013, demonstrators against the government's amnesty bill permanently moved their protest from Samsen railway station to the Democracy Monument on Rajdamnoen Avenue in Phra Nakhon district (PN, Bangkok). They are continuing their protest against the controversial bill seeking blanket amnesty for offenders in corruption and criminal cases.

Medical workers from the Bangkok Hospital gathered in front of their facility to demonstrate against the amnesty bill, as part of thousands of state and private medical workers who did the same nationwide.
A network of health advocates gathered at the Public Health Ministry in Bangkok, in order to show their opposition to the blanket amnesty bill.

Medical workers at Kamphaengphet's Pran Kra Tai hospital led by Dr Banlang Uppapong demonstrated against the amnesty bill in front of their facility as part of thousands of state and private medical workers who did the same nationwide.
Thousands of Chulalongkorn University lecturers, staff, students and alumni gathered in front of the statues of King Rama V and King Rama VI in Bangkok to rally against the amnesty bill.
