A bomb exploded, in a series of five, in Narathiwat's Rueso district. The first bomb went off outside a 7-Eleven in Ban Plai Na. The bomb injured two people.
In Narathiwat's Mueang district, two blasts were reported outside a karaoke bar and shop house in tambon Bang Nak. The blast injured seven people. No other details were reported.
Two bomb blasts occurred next to Kanchanaphisek Park in Narathiwat's Rueso district, in a series of three others that occurred in the province. No other details were reported.

On 4 November 2013, thousands of demonstrators gathered near the Samsen train station in Phaya Thai (PT, Bangkok) for the starting point of a march led by the Democrats in a show of strength against the government's blanket amnesty bill.
Members of the Silom business community gathered on the footpath near the Sala Daeng BTS train station in Bangkok to show their determination to support the government and the monarchy.
A group of 50 villagers from Loei rallied at the Stock Exchange of Thailand to protest against a gold-digging company's attempt to open another mine in the province.

Around 60 demonstrators gathered in Sisaket province to seek to renounce the authority of the International Court of Justice (ICJ) over the Phra Viharn Temple case. The demonstrators are launching a campaign against the Court's ruling on land rights between Thailand and Cambodia.
A roadside bombing in Pattani's Yarang district injured a defense volunteer. The bomb went off as a team of soldiers were on patrol in a village. No other details were reported.

On 19 May 2010, more than 1,000 UDD demonstrators broke through a cordon of police and administrative officials at the City Hall in Khon Kaen city (MKK, KK) to demand the government dissolve the House of Representatives. They brought with them car tyres and fuel and threatened to set fire on the city hall. Clashes between demonstrators and security guards erupted and at least 6 people were injured.
On 19 May 2010, six protesters and volunteer medical personnel died in Wat Pathum and the vicinity in Bangkok when police tried to disperse protesters from the Bangkok center.

On 19 May 2010, a group of persons believed to be affiliated with the UDD red shirts protest movement set fire to the building that housed the Channel 3 television station, causing severe damage in Bangkok . This was in retaliation for the violence and force used to disperse demonstrators earlier on 19 May 2010.
On 19 May 2010, UDD supporters broke into the city hall compound in Mukdahan city (MM, Mukdahan) and burned the building. When the fire trucks responded, they were attacked by the demonstrators.

On 19 May 2010, more than 5,000 UDD red shirts broke through barricades and a cordon of police, soldiers and volunteers and entered the city hall in Udon Thani city (MUT, UT) to protest the government's crackdown on the UDD demonstrators. They set fire to an old building inside the compound which burnt to the ground. The demonstrators clashed with authorities resulting in two being shot dead and 5 people wounded. Demonstrators later gathered at the community radio station.

On 19 May 2010, clashes between troops and demonstrators expanded to Sam Yan area in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok) with demonstrators burning tyres and rolling them into soldiers. During military operations to secure areas around the Ratchaprasong rally site, they fired live ammunition at unarmed demonstrators and journalists resulting in multiple people being killed, including an Italian reporter, and 50 were wounded. Armed Black Shirts mobilized around Rachadamri and in Lumphini Park. A half-hour after the Red Shirt leaders surrendered, a number of demonstrators continued to riot and tried to torch the Central World. Demonstrators also set fire to the TV 3 Channel and library of Stock Exchange, among 15 other spots in Bangkok. Gunfights occurred at the declared "safe zone" Wat Phatum Wanaram resulting in more deaths and numerous injuries, after 2,000 remaining demonstrators sought refuge in the temple after other departure routes were blocked or too dangerous to use. According to the Erawan Emergency Medical Centre reported seven dead and 81 injuries.

On 19 May 2010, there was a grenade attack on a Lumpini police flat in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok). This was later to be alleged to have been done by Mr. Surachai Thewarat, the aide of Major General Khattiya and supporter of the UDD red shirts.

On 19 May 2010, UDD red shirt bikers ignored the curfew and set fires to car tyres throughout Chiang Mai city (MCM, CM) and attacked several Bangkok Bank's branches, setting two fire trucks ablaze, to continue their demonstrations against the government's administration.

On 19 May 2010, the UDD demonstrators were asked and agreed to disperse in the Chiang Rai province, however in the evening, the UDD demonstrators drove a convoy of more than 10 cars in the Chiang Rai municipality (MCM, CM) while being closely monitored by police officers. They dispersed before curfew.

On 18 May 2010, Senator Letrat met with UDD red shirts leaders to try and broker a peace at Ratchaprasong intersection in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok). Later that night, an M79 grenade was fired, convincing the government that the UDD red shirts could not control its demonstrators.

On 18 May 2010, UDD demonstrators hurled Molotov cocktails at the first floor of the Central World in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok) and set fire to tyres outside the building. They also broke windows.
A shooting took place in Kayu Boko, Raman, Yala. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one handgun was used. There were 0 injuries and 1 fatalities.

On 17 May 2010, clashes between Red Shirt demonstrators, the Black Shirts and the military continued for the fourth straight day in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok). M79 grenades were fired at a Dusit Thani Hotel prompting the evacuation of tourists and reporters. A pick-up truck was driven into a restructed area and one person died and one was injured in a gunfire exchange at the Sala Daeng. UDD red shirts continued to burn tyres around Bon Kai community, at Din Daeng Triangle and in front of the Indra Hotel followed by gunfire and bombs. The Black Shirts fired at soldiers near Lumpini Boxing Stadium and in front of Phaya Thai Hospital. According to the Erawan Centre the death toll has risen to 37 with 282 injured people, 8 fatalities were coded for this event.

A shooting took place in Bang Po, Mueang , Narathiwat, Narathiwat. The incident is thought to be related to insurgent activities. At least one firearm of an unknown type was used. There were 1 injuries and 0 fatalities.

On 16 May 2010, UDD demonstrators staged a demonstration outside the provincial hall on the Hua Saphan Bridge in Ubon Ratchathani city (MUR, UR) and set tyres alight to demonstrate against the military action against demonstrators in Bangkok. Soldiers fired warning shots when demonstrators tried to enter Wing 21 air base, forcing them to retreat and eventually disperse.

On 16 May 2010, around 10am a person was shot in the head and seriously injured while demonstrating in front of the Ban Kai community in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok) by the military. Another man was later shot and slightly wounded by unknown gunmen. UDD red shirts set fire to tyres and formed a barricade near the Bon Kai intersection and the Din Daeng intersection. UDD red shirts tried to fire a Bang Fire rocket when it accidentally went off and injured them. According to the Erawan emergency centre the death toll rose to 29 killed and 221 people wounded in the clashes. 5 fatalities coded for this event.

On 16 May 2010, about 500 members of the UDD staged a demonstration at the railway station in Chiang Mai city (MCM, CM) and then marched to the British, US and Chinese consular offices to submit a petition to urge the consulates to pressure the government to refrain from using force against UDD demonstrators at Ratchaprasong intersection in Bangkok.
On 16 May 2010, a group of teenagers burned more than 10 tyres on the Chiang Kham-Chun Road in Chun district (Chun, Phayao) authorities believe in a copycat manner of the red shirts' in Bangkok.

On 16 May 2010, UDD red shirts mobilised supporters from all districts to stage a demonstration at the provincial hall in Phayao city (MP, Phayao) to demand an end to the military violence in Bangkok.

On 16 May 2010, the Royal Elephant Kraal began a demonstration with placards hanging on elephants carrying tourists around the area reading "stop killing, be kind and be peaceful" in Phra Nakhon Si Ayutthaya province (PNSA, PNSA) tu urge the government, the UDD and the armed group to stop using violence.

On 15 May 2010, Red Shirt demonstrators tried to set up new barricades in the Rang Nam, Bon Kai and Klong Toei neighbourhoods in Bangkok to widen their area of control and were met with gunfire. One medic was shot dead in the head and clearly marked journalists and photographers were wounded in those areas. Authorities put up "Live Firing Zone" banners in areas such as Ratchaprarop and Bon Kai where the military was coming under fire. Early in the morning a van driver tried to break the barricade and was injured by troops firing at the tyres of his van. Red Shirt demonstrators shortly thereafter burnt two public phone and a police phone booth near the Thai-Belgium flyover and a garbage truck near Bon Kai. A 10 minute gunfight erupted on Rajprarop Road at 9:20am, injuring a Coke transport worer. At 10:30am three or four residents of Bon Kai were shot and injured by unidentified snipers. Over the rest of the day periodical gunfire, firecrackers and explosions were exchanged. According to the Erawan emergency centre the death toll across 14-15 May rose to 24 people killed and 198 injured during the clashes, 14 fatalities were coded for this event.

On 14 May 2010, there were multiple street battles around the Rajprasong rally site in downtown Bangkok in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok) between Thai military and the UDD red shirt demonstrators. Demonstrators were armed with homemade rockets, petrol bombs and slingshots, they seized a police bus and set in and piles of tires on fire, the troops fired teargas, rubber bullets and eventually live rounds. At night, sporadic outbreaks of gunfire and explosions could still be heard near the US and Japanese embassies in the Bon Kai area. According to the Erawan center ten people died, including at least two Red Shirt security guards, and some 110 were injured, including 3 journalists, one of which was a Canadian. The HRW reported that there were incidents when unarmed demonstrators appear to have been killed with single shots to the head. Three or four M79-triggered explosions occurred at the Sala Daeng areas near the Silom BTS station, but no injuries were reported at this incident.

On 13 May 2010, around 7pm Major General Khattiya was shot in the head by a presumably an army sniper during an interview with a New York Times reporter near Lumphini Park in Pathum Wan district (PW, Bangkok), later dying on 17 May 2010, due to his leadership role with the UDD red shirts and the Black Shirts he brought in to fight the army. Following this attack, armed Black Shirts began firing at soldiers and broke lights to make it harder for army snipers to see. Heavy explosions and gunfire persisted for 20 minutes, and there were gunshots and explosions heard later in the night. They also shot towards the security forces at the Chulalongkorn Hospital which started to shoot back. Demontrators thew stones and fired slingshots and potentially shot firearms at soldiers. One demonstrator was shot in the head and was reported to have later died. There were reports of 20 people injured.
